{"step_by_step_thinking": "The working length of a tooth is the distance from the coronal reference point to the point at which canal preparation and filling should terminate. In an 8-year-old child, the apex of the tooth is not fully formed, so tactile sensation (A) may not be reliable. Moisture on paperpoint (B) is not a method for determining working length. Digital (C) could refer to digital radiography, which is a common method for determining working length, but it's not the most commonly used technique in children due to concerns about radiation exposure. Therefore, none of the options provided are the most commonly used technique for determining the working length of an 8-year-old child's maxillary central incisor.", "answer_choice": "D"}
